{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3352133,"name":"Tyler","username":"Saturnn","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/5e9695/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-04T03:32:16.833Z","cooked":"

So when we were doing spring cleaning I was able to take the Texas Instruments Launchpad. However, I am quite new and am not quite sure where to start with it. Is there anything that might help me with it? My hope/goal would be to have an understanding of it in case our team wanted to use a microcontroller which I know we have struggled with a lot in the past.

If it helps the part number is:
MSP‑EXP430F5529LP

Thanks!

Saturnn:

MSP‑EXP430F5529LP

Here’s the product page on TI’s website

The documentation section has a link to the MSP430 Design Workshop – Student Guide

Which describes how to program it with Code Composer Studio

If you know what an Arduino is, you can do very similar things with the Launchpad; it has generally similar specifications.

If you don’t know what an Arduino is, then I suggest you don’t start with the Launchpad, as there is not a lot of beginner-friendly material out there for it. As alternatives, I would suggest either the Raspberry Pi Pico or the Arduino Uno.

TI charges enormous license fees for commercial use of the SDK for the MSP system. Many startups and small companies build on Arduino or Raspberry Pi or other freeware for that reason.

(To the tune of tens of thousands of dollars a year for access to the SDK, which is not unlike Solidworks, so take that as you will)

s-neff:

TI charges enormous license fees for commercial use of the SDK for the MSP system.

Do you have a source for this? I’ve never heard of any license fee for using these SDKs even for commercial.

A startup I worked with wrote a real big check to renew some kind of development license - I didn’t sign or see that check, it may have been tens of thousands over years rather than per year, he may have included his extra developer seats in that number, but it ate up a lot of his Grant money.

I would suggest that the best way to get started with microcontrollers is with an Arduino. There’s nothing special about the launchpad platform, just give it away.

The original usage for these was to use as a USB HID device, acting as a controller. You could program them with the Gamepad Tool that used to be shipped with the NI Game Tools. The documentation is now all long gone but you can find it on the web archive here: MSP430 LaunchPad Operator Interface for FIRST Robotics Competition - Texas Instruments Wiki
